Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff asserting negligence must prove that the defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiff, that the defendant breached that duty, and that the breach was a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s damages.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf is a New York Court of Appeals decision articulating New York common-law negligence principles, particularly the relational concept of duty and foreseeability, not Massachusetts law. While it discusses duty, breach, and causation in a general tort sense, it neither purports to interpret Massachusetts law nor sets out the Massachusetts elements of a negligence claim. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about what a plaintiff must prove under Massachusetts negligence law.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “In every instance, before negligence can be predicated of a given act, back of the act must be sought and found a duty to the individual complaining, the observance of which would have averted or avoided the injury… The plaintiff sues in her own right for a wrong personal to her… He sues for breach of a duty owing to himself.”

Escola v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal.raw_text: Escola v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal. 2d 453 (1944)
Escola v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff asserting negligence must prove that the defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiff, that the defendant breached that duty, and that the breach was a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s damages.
Escola v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal.case_name: Escola v. Coca Cola Bottling Co.
Escola v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal.support_reasoning: The opinion is a California Supreme Court case discussing res ipsa loquitur and bottler negligence under California law, not the elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law. It neither states nor applies the Massachusetts rule that negligence requires proof of duty, breach, and proximate causation. The only Massachusetts reference is a citation to another case (Ruffin) on exploding bottles, not on the general elements of negligence, so this decision does not support the claimed proposition.
Escola v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal.relevant_excerpt: Res ipsa loquitur does not apply unless (1) defendant had exclusive control of the thing causing the injury and (2) the accident is of such a nature that it ordinarily would not occur in the absence of negligence by the defendant. (Honea v. City Dairy, Inc., 22 Cal.2d 614, 616-617 [140 P.2d 369], and authorities there cited; cf. Hinds v. Wheadon, 19 Cal.2d 458, 461 [121 P.2d 724]; Prosser on Torts [1941], 293-301.)
